p.s: Dermatophytosis caused by dermatophytes of the genera Trichophyton and Microsporum belong to the most frequent mycoses worldwide.
Molecular detection methods proved to be highly sensitive and enable rapid and accurate detection of dermatophyte species from clinical specimens.

For the first time, we compare the performance of different molecular methods with each other and with conventional diagnostics in the detection of dermatophytoses caused by Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton interdigitale in clinical specimens (nail, skin and hair).
The compared molecular methods comprise two already published PCR-ELISAs, a published quantitative RT-PCR as well as a newly developed PCR-ELISA targeting the internal transcribed spacer region.
We investigated the sensitivity of the assays by analysing 375 clinical samples.
In 148 specimens (39.5%) a positive result was gained in at least one of the four molecular tests or by culture, but the number of detected agents differed significantly between some of the assays.

The most sensitive assay, a PCR-ELISA targeting a microsatellite region, detected 81 T. rubrum infections followed by an internal transcribed spacer PCR-ELISA (60), quantitative RT-PCR (52) and a topoisomerase II PCR-ELISA (51), whereas cultivation resulted in T. rubrum identification in 37 samples.
The pros and cons of all four tests in routine diagnostics are discussed.
Rapid and sensitive detection of dermatophytes is of great importance because most superficial fungal infections are caused by this group of fungi [1,2].
Their accurate identification is essential for the choice of the most appropriate antifungal treatment and for tracking sources of infection, thereby helping to avoid re-infection [3].
Culture-based identification is the current reference standard but has a high false-negative rate and requires up to 6 weeks incubation time [4].
In recent years numerous molecular tests for dermatophyte detection have been developed that proved to be more sensitive than traditional examinations [5e10].
Even though all of these molecular assays have shown a significantly higher sensitivity over conventional methods they may show considerable differences in sensitivity and specificity.
The increasing number of molecular detection assays raises the search for a promising molecular 'in house' approach that meets most of the user-specific conditions and requirements.
Therefore studies are necessary that not only compare conventional diagnostics and single molecular detection assays but also include different molecular assays.
The specific characteristics of molecular assays, such as the hands-on time, technical effort and costs of consumables and technical equipment, require detailed considerations before application.
The close phylogenetic relationship of clinically relevant dermatophyte species demands the use of highly variable genetic target regions in molecular detection assays [11].

Therefore, we and others have used the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region, a microsatellite region and the topoisomerase II gene for the development of a quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) and several PCR-ELISAs [6,8,12,13].
One of the PCR-ELISAs is introduced in the present study.
This assay is based on the ITS region for the detection of the most prevalent dermatophyte species Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton interdigitale.

To our knowledge this is the first study comparing the performance of different in-house PCR tests (qRT-PCR and three PCR-ELISAs) and conventional diagnostics (culture and microscopy) using an identical clinical sample set.

Analytical specificity and analytical sensitivity of the ITS-ELISA were determined using reference strains from the Centraalbureau voor Schimmelcultures (Utrecht, the Netherlands) as well as clinical isolates from our laboratory (see Supplementary material, Tables S1 and S2).
Patients visiting a surgical emergency department during a 3month period showing clinical signs suggestive of tinea pedis and/or onychomycosis were included in this study.
In total, the clinical sample set comprised 207 patients, 167 patients with a nail and skin specimen each, 20 patients with a single nail specimen and 20 patients with a single skin specimen.

Included patients showed the following clinical signs: ulcerations of the lower legs and feet due to chronic venous insufficiency (varicosis, ulcus cruris venosum), peripheral artery occlusive disease, diabetic foot syndrome (malum perforans), lymphoedema (idiopathic, postinflammatory, post-surgical) and stasis dermatitis (dermatitis varicosa).
As control group, 20 nail specimens from healthy students were tested using qRT-PCR, microsatellite and ITS PCR-ELISA.
Large nail fragments were cut into small pieces using a sterile scalpel; a minimum of 3 mg of skin scrapes or nail fragments was used for DNA extraction.
Each specimen was divided into equal parts for culture, microscopy and PCR analysis.

For reasons of reproducibility and statistics, the molecular detection tests were restricted to T. rubrum and T. interdigitale, which are by far the most common species, frequently causing onychomycosis and tinea pedis in central Europe.

Direct microscopy with calcofluor white and culture on Sabouraud 4%/glucose agar and selective agar for dermatophytes (Sabouraud 4%/glucose agar þ 100 mg/L cycloheximide) were performed in M€ olbis, Germany (Labor für medizinische Mikrobiologie).
Cultures were grown at 28 C for 3À4 weeks and clinical isolates were identified on the basis of phenotypic characteristics like colony shape and shape/size of macrocondia and microconidia [14,15].

DNA from all 375 specimens was extracted using the QIAamp DNA Mini kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions (protocol for animal tissue) including an overnight lysis with proteinase K.
The isolated DNA was finally eluted with 70 ml of buffer AE and stored at À20 C.

For 275 specimens DNA extraction was additionally performed using the Illustra genomicPrep Mini Spin Kit (GE Healthcare, Freiburg, Germany) following the manufacturer's protocol with minor modifications (proteinase K digestion was performed overnight and RNase A treatment at 37 C, elution of DNA was carried out twice with 70 ml of elution buffer in the same reaction tube).
Afterwards the DNA solution was concentrated by evaporation (using a Concentrator 5301, Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany) at 60 C to a final volume of approximately 30 ml.
A qRT-PCR was used to detect the most common dermatophytes in nail, skin and hair samples (T.
rubrum and T. interdigitale) on species level [12].
The test was performed in separate tubes by using different TaqMan probes and primer pairs in 20-ml reaction volumes on a LightCycler 480 (Roche Applied Science, Mannheim, Germany).
The reaction mixtures, including an internal amplification control were carried out as described elsewhere [12].

The applied PCR-ELISAs are based on three different genomic target regions that are amplified in separate reactions (the topoisomerase II gene (TI-ELISA), a microsatellite-marker (MS-ELISA) and the ITS region (ITS-ELISA)).
In all three assays, one primer is labelled with digoxigenin.

The detection of digoxigenin-labelled amplification products was carried out using the commercial available PCR ELISA digoxigenin Detection Kit (Roche, Mannheim, Germany), according to the manufacturer's instructions [8].
Per reaction 7.5 pmol/mL 5 0 -biotinylated probe was used.
Hybridization was performed at 55 C for 2.5 h.
Detection was carried out with 2,2 0 -azino-bis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulphonic acid) (ABTS) or 3,3 0 ,5,5 0 -tetramethylbenzidine for TI-ELISA.
A negative control without adding a PCR product was included in each run.
The TI-ELISA was performed in M€ olbis, Germany (Labor für medizinische Mikrobiologie) but initially developed by Beifuss et al. [13] and modified by Winter et al. [16].

As a limitation of the TI-ELISA, T. interdigitale cannot be distinguished from Trichophyton tonsurans/Trichophyton equinum, because of the high nucleotide sequence similarities of the targeted topoisomerase II gene [13,17].
The detailed procedure is described elsewhere [16].
The MS-ELISA was developed for the species-specific diagnosis of T. rubrum only (not developed for the detection of T. interdigitale [8]).
The PCR is based on a primer that amplifies a 280-bp fragment containing a GT-microsatellite repeat specific for strains of the T. rubrum/Trichophyton violaceum clade.
The procedure includes an internal amplification control.
Details can be found elsewhere [8].
The ITS-ELISA is a nested PCR and enables the species-specific detection of T. rubrum using the biotin-labelled probe T.rubrum_-BIO (5 0 -Bio-aatgggcagccaatyca).
Using another probe (T.inter_BIO, 5 0 -Bio-cggcgcccccgtcttt) a species complex, comprising T. interdigitale, T. tonsurans and T. equinum can be detected.
Speciesspecific discrimination of T. interdigitale is achieved by using an additional T. tonsurans/T.
equinum-specific probe (T.tons_BIO, 5 0 -Bio-gccggccccccaggata).

PCR amplification of the ITS region is performed as a nested PCR approach with an external primer pair spanning the entire ITS1 and ITS2 region (V9D and Mas266 [18]) and subsequently two internal primer pairs amplifying ITS1 or ITS2.
For the detection of T. rubrum and T. interdigitale, ITS3a (5 0 -gcagaattccgtgaatcatc) and ITS4 [19] were used and ITS1 and ITS2 [19] were used for T. tonsurans/T.
equinum.
Both nested reverse primers (ITS2 and ITS4) were labelled with digoxigenin.

The reaction mixtures (external and internal) of 35 ml contained 3.5 ml of 10Â reaction buffer (GeneAmp 10Â PCR Buffer, ABI, Weiterstadt, Germany), 7 ml Q-Solution (Qiagen), 0.14 mM of each primer, 62.5 mM of each dNTP, 1.5 mM MgCl 2 , 1.5 units of Taq DNA polymerase (AmpliTaq, ABI) and 1 ml of DNA for the external and 0.5 ml for the nested PCR.

The cycling profile for the first-round amplification consisted of an initial denaturation step at 96 C for 3 min, followed by 30 cycles with 30 seconds at 96 C, 15 seconds at 56 C, 1: 20 min at 72 C and a final extension of 1 min at 72 C. The cycling profile for nested PCR differed in the elongation time, which was 30 seconds and the number of cycles was 35.
In each run we included a single positive and 10% negative controls.

div.head: Analytical sensitivity and specificity of the ITS-PCR-ELISA

p.s: The analytical sensitivity of the ITS-ELISA was determined by running serial dilutions of purified T. rubrum and T. interdigitale genomic DNA in triplicate.
Serial dilutions for sensitivity tests comprised 20 ng, 10 ng, 1n g, 100 pg, 1 pg, 100 fg per reaction.
The analytical sensitivity was defined as the lowest DNA concentration that produced OD-values > 0.15 OD for ITS-ELISA in all three repeats.

The specificity of the assay was analysed using approximately 20 ng genomic DNA of T. interdigitale and T. rubrum strains and strains of closely related species (see Supplementary material, Table S1).
Diagnostic sensitivity and specificity were not calculated in this study because it is known that culture is an imperfect reference standard due to its comparably low sensitivity.
Currently there is no better reference method available.
Instead, performance of the molecular tests is statistically compared using a simple chi-square test with a confidence interval of minimum 95%.
The specificity of the assay was determined by analysing genomic DNA of T. interdigitale and T. rubrum strains and closely related dermatophyte species.
For probe T.inter_BIO positive results were obtained with strains of T. interdigitale, T. tonsurans and T. equinum.
To identify T. interdigitale unambiguously, an additional T. tonsurans/T.
equinum-specific probe T.tons_BIO was used, which gave positive results with T. tonsurans and T. equinum strains, but remained negative with T. interdigitale (see Supplementary material, Table S1).
The T. rubrum-specific probe T.rubrum_BIO was only positive with T. rubrum.
No signal was obtained for related species, including the closest relative T. violaceum (see Supplementary material, Table S1).
On the basis of sequence alignments it was further confirmed that the probes have no sequence identities to other potential agents of dermatophytosis.

The analytical sensitivity of the ITS-ELISA was 100 fg for genomic DNA of T. rubrum, 1 pg for T. interdigitale and 1 pg for T. tonsurans (see Supplementary material, Table S2), which is about the same magnitude as determined for the other assays: the limit of detection (LoD) for all assays was in pg-range.
For the qRT-PCR the LoD was 1e5 pg for T. rubrum and T. interdigitale [12].
The LoD for the MS-ELISA was 3.5 pg for T. rubrum DNA [8] and 1 pg for T. rubrum DNA in the TI-ELISA (T.
interdigitale strains have not been tested [13]).
Of 375 samples 210 (56%) gave negative results with all four molecular assays as well as in conventional diagnostics.
Among the remaining 165 specimens direct microscopy revealed fungal elements and spores in 76 (20.3%) of the samples and 49 (13.1%)
samples were positive in culture.
The number of positive results detected for each of the four molecular test assays differed considerably (Table 1).

MS-ELISA detected by far the most infections by T. rubrum, followed by the ITS-ELISA, whereas the number of infections caused by T. interdigitale was the highest with the ITS-ELISA, followed by TI-ELISA (Table 1).

According to the number of dermatophyte-positive samples, all molecular detection methods were considerably more sensitive than culture, as illustrated in Fig. 1: samples which were dermatophyte-positive with at least two molecular methods were significantly less frequently positive in culture.
In contrast, there were seven positive specimens that were identified as T. rubrum or T. interdigitale by culture, whereas none of the molecular tests supported that result.
Unfortunately the identities of cultures obtained from these specimens have not been confirmed by sequencing.
In eight specimens (2.1%) potential pathogenic nondermatophyte fungi were found in culture, while T. rubrum was detected by molecular methods (Table 2).
Mixed infections of T. rubrum and T. interdigitale were found in eight samples (2.1 %).
Two of these samples have been isolated from nail and skin specimen from the same patient (samples 100N and 100H, Table 2).

div.head: Influence of the DNA extraction method

p.s: A subset of DNA samples (n ¼ 100) was extracted using the QIAamp DNA Mini Kit (Qiagen) and another subset of 275 specimens were processed using the Illustra genomic Prep Mini Spin Kit (GE Healthcare).
Only for the TI-ELISA were all 375 samples (both subsets) uniformly extracted using the QIAamp DNA Mini Kit.
This allowed evaluation of the impact of the DNA-isolation method on the test outcomes.
With the TI-ELISA the same percentage of dermatophyte positives was detected in both subsets (Fig. 2).
For all other methods the percentage of dermatophyte positives was slightly higher using the QIAamp DNA Mini Kit than using the Illustra genomic Prep Mini Spin Kit (Fig. 2).
This effect was most pronounced in the ITS-ELISA with a difference of 7.6% between the two DNA extraction methods, but was not statistically relevant (p >0.2 in Chi-square tests).
There was also no significant difference in the detection rate among nail and skin samples within the results of any detection test (including culture and microscopy).
The performances of the molecular assay varied significantly.
Using MS-ELISA, for example, 30 (37%) more T. rubrum-infections were identified than using TI-ELISA (Table 1).

However, the sensitivity of the molecular assays determined by serial dilutions of fungal reference strain DNA (in range of 1e5 pg) did not reflect the sensitivity observed by applying the tests to clinical samples.
For example, the TI-ELISA with the highest sensitivity of 1 pg was least sensitive in detecting T. rubrum from clinical samples.
That inconsistency cast doubt on the reliability of LoDs determined by serial dilutions of pure fungal DNA only.
One reason may be that LoDs were determined in separate laboratories using different fungal reference strains during the development of the respective molecular assay.
The smallest proportion of dermatophyte positives was detected by culture.

This results was not unexpected as limited sensitivity of culture has been reported before [7,20e22] and is possibly caused by overgrowing of the slow-growing dermatophytes by yeasts and moulds or by unequal distribution of fungal elements in clinical specimens.
The effect was more pronounced for T. interdigitale.
Here the detection rate of culture was significantly lower than for all molecular methods (Table 1).
This was also found by Winter et al. [16] and is probably because T. interdigitale more often fails to grow on culture plates than T. rubrum.
Due to the poor performance of culture we reject calculation of diagnostic sensitivity and specificity of the molecular tests, based on culture as the reference standard.
In this study the MS-ELISA has an outstanding sensitivity in the detection of T. rubrum with 26 positive samples, whereas all other methods gave negative results (Table 1, Fig. 1).
Still, 12 T. rubrumpositive samples were identified solely when using one of the three other molecular assays or by culture (Fig. 1).

For T. interdigitale by far the most positives were detected using the newly developed ITS-ELISA: Twenty-three T. interdigitale infections were exclusively identified using ITS-ELISA, four using TI-ELISA, two using qRT-PCR and two by culture (Fig. 1).
The high number of positives, especially detected by MS-ELISA (T.
rubrum) and ITS-ELISA (T.
interdigitale), which did not correspond to any of the other detection methods are very likely true infections as all specimens of the healthy control group remained negative with all methods.
It is assumed that these methods are highly sensitive and are able to detect extremely low quantities of dermatophyte fungi whereas for other methods the detection limit is reached.

Positive results by a single molecular assay cannot be explained by inhomogeneous distribution of fungal elements alone because three molecular assays were performed on an identical DNA extraction batch.
However, the choice of the target region and the selection of primers and probes surely have important impacts on the sensitivity of molecular assays [23].
Furthermore, the amplicon size, the volume and concentration as well as the age of template DNA are critical factors.
The volume of inserted template DNA is particularly important in clinical samples because they contain inhibitory substances to an unknown and fluctuating amount.

Although internal amplification controls performed for MS-ELISA and qRT-PCR did not result in reduced amplification, minor impacts of inhibitory substances might not have recognizable effects on the internal amplification control but can still depress target amplification beneath the detection limit.
Compared with the total volume of the PCR mix the final volume share of DNA, except for ITS-ELISA, was very similar.

The highest DNA concentration was added to qRT-PCRs (2.5 ml DNA in 20 ml reaction volume) followed by TI-ELISA (6 ml in 50 ml), MS-ELISA (4 ml in 35 ml) and ITS-ELISA (1 ml in 35 ml for firstround PCR).
Hence, the observed sensitivity obviously did not correlate with the DNA volume in our study.

Also the storage time of DNA did not correlate with the proportion of positive samples for TI-ELISA and MS-ELISA, which showed the highest discrepancies concerning sensitivity when performed in parallel directly after DNA extraction, whereas the other assays were performed approximately 1 year later.
Also, the length of the amplified fragments directly affects the sensitivity of molecular assays and is of special importance to attain efficient qRT-PCR [23].

The amplicon size of our qRT-PCR for detection has a length of 423 bp for T. rubrum and 205 bp for T. interdigitale, which is comparably long and may cause a reduced sensitivity compared with MS-ELISA.
According to Bustin [23] the optimal amplicon length for real-time RT-PCR is <100 bp.
For eight (2.1%) samples with one or more methods T. rubrum was detected, whereas at least one method identified T. interdigitale.
It is assumed that in these samples mixed infections of both dermatophytes were present.
This result is comparable to other studies (0.85%e2.2%) [7,10,24].
However, it is noticeable that none of the methods detected both dermatophytes in the same sample, simultaneously.

This may be due to varying sensitivity of different methods for the detection of both species: In five of eight mixed infections MS-ELISA was positive for T. rubrum, whereas ITS-ELISA detected most of the T. interdigitale infections (Table 2).

For the other three samples individual differences in detection may be due to different PCR conditions, which may influence the inhibiting effect of impurities present in the DNA preparations or varying availability of the different target regions caused by partial degradation of the genomic DNA.
The problem of missing mixed infections was also encountered with culture: In three of eight of the respective samples a T. rubrum was identified, whereas only one comprises T. interdigitale.
It is known that in mixed infections the predominant dermatophyte species (T.
rubrum) is likely to outperform the slower-growing species (T.
interdigitale) [25].
In eight samples a non-dermatophyte was identified in addition to T. rubrum (Table 2).
In the presence of a dermatophyte, however, non-dermatophytes are generally not regarded as causes of infection, but as innocuous contaminants [26].

div.head: Influence of the DNA extraction method

p.s: In clinical samples a variable and sometimes substantial amount of human DNA and inhibitory substances can hamper an efficient extraction of DNA and influence the performance of subsequent tests [27].
In that respect, we compared two different methods to extract DNA of clinical samples (QIAamp DNA Mini Kit and Illustra genomic Prep Mini Spin Kit).

Although the number of identified positive samples did not differ significantly between the two batches, we found for all tested methods a slight surplus of dermatophyte positives when DNA extraction was performed with the QiaAmp Mini DNA Kit (Fig. 2).

It should be mentioned, though, that with culture the fraction of specimens that was used for DNA extraction with the QiaAmp kit also yielded more dermatophytes than the fraction that was processed with the Illustra kit (17% versus 11.6% positives, respectively).
Hence, it is likely that just by coincidence the first part contained more dermatophyte infections than the latter one.
All the described molecular assays were much more sensitive than culture.

However, a good molecular detection system should not only be selected on the basis of its sensitivity, it is equally important how long, complex and expensive the necessary steps of a procedure are and if the species-spectrum that can be detected by an assay is appropriate (Table 3).

Even though the MS-ELISA has a superior sensitivity, its use is limited to the detection of T. rubrum and as it is based on a T. rubrum-specific microsatellite region it cannot easily be expanded to other species.

However, the detection of prevalent dermatophytes at a species-level is important to identify likely sources of infection (like potential animal origin) and so avoid reinfection and to investigate and control epidemics [3].

The other tested methods are more suitable on this issue: The qRT-PCR can detect all relevant dermatophyte species [12], whereas the species spectrum of ITS-ELISA and TI-ELISA is limited but could be easily expanded to cover more species.

The ITS-ELISA was highly sensitive in the detection of T. interdigitale (best results among the methods tested here) and T. rubrum (second best method) but its time-consuming doublerounded PCR approach and the resulting high risk for carry-over contaminations [28] lower the suitability of this assay for routine diagnostics in high-throughput laboratories.

The TI-ELISA is comparable to the qRT-PCR in terms of sensitivity; concerning specificity, however, it is noticeable that the ITS region has a higher diversity among dermatophytes and so has a higher discrimination power than the topoisomerase region, which was used for the TI-ELISA.

Generally, the required technical devices are less expensive for ELISAs compared with qRT-PCR, as they do not require costly fluorescence labels, which make the ELISA technique attractive for laboratories with low sample throughput, even though it is more elaborate and time-consuming.
Advantages of the qRT-PCR are the short handling time and the option to quantify the fungal load, monitor the therapy success and determine the extent of inhibitions in clinical samples.
The high acquisition costs of a qRT-PCR cycler can be compensated for by the comparatively low costs per sample in high-throughput diagnostic laboratories.
